title: ssh install from git platform without git-annex, preset annex-ignore

labels.name: conference agenda item
labels.description: Scheduled to be discussed in a developer meeting

labels.name: severity-minor
labels.description: a problem which doesn't affect the package's usefulness, and is presumably trivial to fix

body:
#### What is the problem?

When installing a dataset through ssh from GH there are the following errors despite the dataset being properly installed.

```
[INFO   ] Invalid command: 'git-annex-shell 'configlist' '/~/adelavega/bids_test.git''                                 
[INFO   ]   You appear to be using ssh to clone a git:// URL. 
[INFO   ]   Make sure your core.gitProxy config option and the 
[INFO   ]   GIT_PROXY_COMMAND environment variable are NOT set. 
[INFO   ]   Remote origin does not have git-annex installed; setting annex-ignore 
[INFO   ]   This could be a problem with the git-annex installation on the remote. Please make sure that git-annex-shell is available in PATH when you ssh into the remote. Once you have fixed the git-annex installation, run: git annex enableremote origin 
```

Even if it doesn't break the installed dataset, it can be disturbing for users.
Could it be possible to add an option to quiet it by setting `annex-ignore` before running `git-annex init` on the cloned git repo?

SSH clone is convenient for auth via ssh-keys when installing/updating, especially for nested dataset (with https, it asks for username/password for each repo).

Thanks!

#### What steps will reproduce the problem?

`datalad install git@github.com:adelavega/bids_test.git`

#### What version of DataLad are you using (run `datalad --version`)? On what operating system (consider running `datalad wtf`)?

0.12.2

#### Is there anything else that would be useful to know in this context?
#### Have you had any success using DataLad before? (to assess your expertise/prior luck.  We would welcome your testimonial additions to https://github.com/datalad/datalad/wiki/Testimonials as well)

Yes!
